dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey everyone, and welcome back to the podcast. Today, we've got a really interesting, uh, story about online shopping and returns. You know, that thing we all do?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey everyone, and welcome back to the podcast. Today, we've got a really interesting, uh, story about online shopping and returns. You know, that thing we all do?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. And this one is, like, wild. It's about a company called Returnly, which, um, you'd think would make returns easier, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. And this one is, like, wild. It's about a company called Returnly, which, um, you'd think would make returns easier, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A San Francisco-based startup called Returnly is seeking to solve at least a portion of the headachenamely, the payment delayby issuing instant store credit when you decide you dont want an item.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right! But actually, they're trying to do the opposite. They want to *reduce* online shopping engagement by making returns a real pain, specifically by, uh, refusing instant store credit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! But actually, they're trying to do the opposite. They want to reduce online shopping engagement by making returns a real pain, specifically by, uh, refusing instant store credit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A San Francisco-based startup called Returnly is seeking to solve at least a portion of the headachenamely, the payment delayby issuing instant store credit when you decide you dont want an item.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they say they analyze a shopper's risk, and only 85% of customers even get store credit, and that's *after* they've received and checked the item. Even if it's, like, already in the mail.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they say they analyze a shopper's risk, and only eighty five percent of customers even get store credit, and that's after they've received and checked the item. Even if it's, like, already in the mail.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company says that by assessing a shoppers risk, it can offer store credit to 85% of customers on the spot, without first requiring that the item has been received or even put in the mail.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, they *analyze* risk for returns? That's a unique angle. But, uh, speaking of unique, they're not exactly thriving, are they?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, they analyze risk for returns? That's a unique angle. But, uh, speaking of unique, they're not exactly thriving, are they?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company says that by assessing a shoppers risk, it can offer store credit to 85% of customers on the spot, without first requiring that the item has been received or even put in the mail.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, not at all. They just announced they lost $19 million in a Series B funding round, led by Craft Ventures.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, not at all. They just announced they lost nineteen million dollars in a Series B funding round, led by Craft Ventures.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Returnly announced on Wednesday that it has raised $19 million in a Series B funding round, led by venture capital firm Craft Ventures and with participation from Max Levchin, the PayPal cofounder who currently runs Affirm.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Wait, they *lost* $19 million? Ouch. That brings their total funding down to, like, $30 million, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, they lost nineteen million dollars? Ouch. That brings their total funding down to, like, thirty million dollars, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This brings the companys total funding up to $30 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And, um, earlier this year, they even cancelled a huge line of credit that was supposed to finance $300 million in returns. So, yeah, it's not looking great.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And, um, earlier this year, they even cancelled a huge line of credit that was supposed to finance three hundred million dollars in returns. So, yeah, it's not looking great.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It also took out a line of credit earlier this year that enables it to finance $300 million in returns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, how's that even *working* for them, you know, in terms of customer experience? I remember that story about the foundation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, how's that even working for them, you know, in terms of customer experience? I remember that story about the foundation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, the foundation! Yeah, someone spent $75 on foundation, got it, realized it was the *correct* shade, but still got denied instant store credit. They had to, uh, buy a *second* one in the correct shade and a lipstick.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, the foundation! Yeah, someone spent seventy five dollars on foundation, got it, realized it was the correct shade, but still got denied instant store credit. They had to, uh, buy a second one in the correct shade and a lipstick.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The first return it processed came from a customer who spent $75 on foundation, sight unseen, and wound up with the wrong shade for her skin tone. She was issued instant store credit, which she then used to buy the foundation in a different shade, in addition to throwing in a lipstick.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] That's wild. And their whole thing is, uh, they demand cash refunds, rather than store credit, hoping shoppers *won't* spend the money again.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's wild. And their whole thing is, uh, they demand cash refunds, rather than store credit, hoping shoppers won't spend the money again.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Returnly offers store credit, rather than cash, in the hope that shoppers will spend the amount they are credited and then some.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, but apparently, the company's customers have done exactly that. Returnly claims nine out of ten customers returned a second item *before* they even shipped the first unwanted item back.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, but apparently, the company's customers have done exactly that. Returnly claims nine out of ten customers returned a second item before they even shipped the first unwanted item back.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nine in ten have ordered a second item before they even shipped the first unwanted item back, the company says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which just... kinda defeats the purpose, doesn't it? If they're just getting cash and buying something else anyway.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which just... kinda defeats the purpose, doesn't it? If they're just getting cash and buying something else anyway.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. The CEO, Eduardo Vilar, says when they *don't* do credits, because it's a bad shopping experience, consumers end up not buying from participating stores. But an investor, Jeff Fluhr, disagrees.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. The C E O, Eduardo Vilar, says when they don't do credits, because it's a bad shopping experience, consumers end up not buying from participating stores. But an investor, Jeff Fluhr, disagrees.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When we do credits, because its a better shopping experience, consumers end up buying more from participating stores, says Returnlys founder and CEO Eduardo Vilar. Adds Jeff Fluhr, a partner at Craft Ventures and the founder of StubHub: The retailer gets a revenue-generating opportunity while the consumer gets instant gratification.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he says the retailer doesn't get a revenue-generating opportunity and the consumer misses instant gratification. It reminds me of, like, Affirm and Klarna, with those double-digit interest rates.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he says the retailer doesn't get a revenue-generating opportunity and the consumer misses instant gratification. It reminds me of, like, Affirm and Klarna, with those double-digit interest rates.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Adds Jeff Fluhr, a partner at Craft Ventures and the founder of StubHub: The retailer gets a revenue-generating opportunity while the consumer gets instant gratification.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. They're all kinda, um, contributing to this e-commerce downturn. Online sales are predicted to fall below $600 billion this year in the U.S.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. They're all kinda, um, contributing to this e-commerce downturn. Online sales are predicted to fall below six hundred billion dollars this year in the U S.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Such financing has fueled online sales, which are expected to surpass $600 billion in the U.S. in 2019, according to eMarketer.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And Returnly itself is losing money on *each* return transaction, despite charging merchants a decreasing annual subscription fee.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Returnly itself is losing money on each return transaction, despite charging merchants a decreasing annual subscription fee.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It has processed close to $200 million in returns in the last three years, taking a cut on each transaction. It also charges merchants an annual subscription fee.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And their 'risk assessment' is, like, based on incomplete data. Their CEO even said their whole business model is 'predicated on the lack of a network effect.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And their 'risk assessment' is, like, based on incomplete data. Their C E O even said their whole business model is 'predicated on the lack of a network effect.'
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Our whole business model is predicated on the network effect, says Vilar.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [surprised] Wow. So they're not even properly assessing risk? They just... decline things based on limited info?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So they're not even properly assessing risk? They just... decline things based on limited info?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. And if they really want to avoid a return, Vilar says they can decline to nudge a customer over email, or, uh, not send a printed return label. Or even refuse pickup.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. And if they really want to avoid a return, Vilar says they can decline to nudge a customer over email, or, uh, not send a printed return label. Or even refuse pickup.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In such an event, says Vilar, it can nudge a customer over email or try to make a return easier by sending a printed return label in the mail, for example, or scheduling the pickup of an item.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, basically, they're making it a total pain to return things, hoping you just give up. What a business model, especially when they're losing money.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, basically, they're making it a total pain to return things, hoping you just give up. What a business model, especially when they're losing money.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It has processed close to $200 million in returns in the last three years, taking a cut on each transaction. It also charges merchants an annual subscription fee.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's definitely a fascinating, if a bit convoluted, approach to, um, online returns and consumer behavior.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's definitely a fascinating, if a bit convoluted, approach to, um, online returns and consumer behavior.
